sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Welcome back! I’m Jihad Al Sayed, and today we’re tackling one of the most powerful ideas in linear algebra — linearly independent sets and the concept of a basis. If you want to understand vector spaces deeply, this is it.

sections.title: What is Linear Independence?
sections.content: A set of vectors is linearly independent if no vector in the set can be written as a linear combination of the others. If you can’t recreate one vector using the rest — it’s independent.

sections.title: Testing Independence
sections.math:
Set up Ax = 0 where A has your vectors as columns.
If the only solution is the trivial one (x = 0), then they are independent.

sections.title: What is a Basis?
sections.content: A basis is a set of linearly independent vectors that span the whole space. It’s like a minimal toolkit to build every other vector in the space.

sections.title: Example: Basis of ℝ²
sections.math: \{[1, 0], [0, 1]\} is a basis for \mathbb{R}^2 — it spans the plane and is linearly independent.

sections.title: Real-World Application
sections.content: In machine learning, choosing a good basis helps reduce dimensions while preserving information — think PCA (Principal Component Analysis).

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: Today we looked at what it means for vectors to be independent, how to test it, what a basis is, and why these ideas are the blueprint of every vector space you’ll ever work with.
